text: [music playing]

ZOEY TUR: OJ Simpson
transcended color.
He was a celebrity.
He was loved.

And now, below me,
I'm watching a man

running from the police who
might very well find himself,

like many black men,
at the end of a gun
and being shot to death.

DANA VAHLE: Oh, I'd
done other chases.

That was not unusual to do,
but this one certainly was.

And as they characterized
it as the low-speed chase,
and it was.
[music playing]

I think it was a couple
of months before that.

I had worked on a TV
movie called "Frogmen"
that OJ was the star of it.
Really?

I'm going to go from having
worked on a TV movie with him
to this?

- What are you
seeing down there?

ZOEY TUR: The people showing
up on the sides of the freeways

and waving, like this
was some sort of game,

that this was some
sort of parade.
It wasn't.
Two people were dead.

A man was wanted
now by the police,

and he might find
himself dead for refusing
to give himself up.
[music playing]

Al Cowlings made the left
turn, pulled into the driveway.

And it was there that
there was a standoff.

And the negotiators
were talking to OJ.

But what OJ didn't know, and
what the public didn't know,

is in my ear, I'm also
listening to the LAPD SWAT team
talking on their two-way radios.

And what they were saying, was
they had him in their sights.

Nobody wanted to shoot OJ
Simpson on live television.
[music playing]

- Why do you think people
are still fascinated
with the OJ Simpson story?

DANA VAHLE: It
just re-illustrates

the divide in people,
that people lined
up on certain sides right away.

ZOEY TUR: He had the traditional
African-American experience

in this nation, and he
was able to succeed.
He went right to the very top.

And it gave African-American
kids, families hope.

And then to see it devolve
into a slow-speed pursuit,
wanted for two homicides.
- Shocking to everybody, really.

ZOEY TUR: Not just
shocking, but demoralizing.
